The One Issue I Must Resolve

â¤ï¸ Krishna Chaitanya September 17, 2022

A Silent Battle Within

The one thing that has haunted me for years is my pulse rate. It has never been normal. Not once. Not for a single day. A resting heart rate of 100 BPMâ€”consistently. No one around me seems to care. No one takes it seriously. But I do. Because I know what it means. I know that something isnâ€™t right.

This is not a new discovery. I first measured my pulse in 2017â€”101 BPM. At the time, I ignored it, thinking maybe it was temporary. But it never changed. Year after year, the numbers remained the same. I spent an entire year swimming, trying to bring it down. Nothing. A mere 90 BPM at best. Still abnormal. Why?

Am I overthinking? Maybe. Or maybe no one else is thinking at all.

â¸»

The Connection No One Sees

I decided to break this problem apart, analyze it in ways no one else would. And I found somethingâ€”everything is connected, perfectly interlinked.

My Metabolism:

Iâ€™ve always had a high metabolism. My body burns calories too fast, preventing me from gaining weight, from aging normally, from growing the way I should. It sounds like a gift. It isnâ€™t. A metabolism running at full speed means my heart is working overtime, always engaged, always pumping, never resting.

The Pulse Rate:

A heart rate of 100 BPM means my heart beats 100 times per minute, even when Iâ€™m resting. Thatâ€™s 144,000 beats per dayâ€”millions more per year than a normal heart should endure. Theoretically, my body should be more efficient because of it. More blood flow, faster oxygen delivery, quicker responses. But at what cost?

The cost is simple: a shorter heart lifespan. The more my heart works now, the less time it will last in the future. I cannot afford that risk.

What they donâ€™t tell you about an abnormal heart rate is how it affects the mind.

A constantly elevated pulse triggers the release of cortisol, the stress hormone. Cortisol keeps the body in a perpetual state of alertness, making it harder to relax, harder to sleep, harder to think clearly. This is why I experience light sleep, frequent awakenings, andâ€”most frustrating of allâ€”bad dreams.

More time in REM sleep means more nightmares. More stress. More exhaustion. Itâ€™s a vicious cycle, one that keeps breaking me down mentally while my body appears to function perfectly.

â¸»

The Only Solution

I need to reset everything. My heart, my stress levels, my sleep. I need to lower my resting heart rate to 75 BPMâ€”no exceptions.

There is only one way to do this: cardio training. Running. There is no pool here. No skating rink. Nothing that would make this process enjoyable. But it doesnâ€™t matter. I have no other option.

I have to run.

This is not just about physical health. This is about taking back control of my own mind. The elevated heart rate, the constant stress, the nightmaresâ€”these things have shaped me into someone I donâ€™t recognize. They have altered my emotions, my thoughts, my reality.

I Dont want to let this continue.

I will try â€”fix this.
